body.name: AMD Ryzen™ 7 7700X 8-Core, 16-Thread Unlocked Desktop Processor

features: This dominant gaming processor can deliver fast 100+ FPS performance in the world's most popular games
8 Cores and 16 processing threads, based on AMD "Zen 4" architecture

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Product for an Excellent prize
reviews.reviewText: I recently purchased the AMD Ryzen™ 7 7700X 8-Core, 16-Thread Unlocked Desktop Processor, and I couldn't be more thrilled with its performance. This processor has truly exceeded my expectations in every way possible.The sheer power of the 8 cores and 16 threads allows for seamless multitasking, making it perfect for demanding applications and resource-intensive tasks. Whether I'm gaming, video editing, or running multiple applications simultaneously, the Ryzen 7 7700X handles it all effortlessly.The unlocked nature of this processor adds a layer of versatility for enthusiasts and overclockers. I've been able to push its limits and fine-tune its performance to match my specific needs, providing an extra boost for demanding workloads.What truly sets the Ryzen 7 7700X apart is its efficiency and thermal performance. Even under heavy loads, the processor remains cool and quiet, thanks to AMD's advanced architecture. This not only enhances the overall user experience but also contributes to the longevity of the processor.The compatibility of the Ryzen 7 7700X with the latest technologies ensures that my system is future-proofed. It seamlessly integrates with PCIe 4.0, providing lightning-fast data transfer speeds, and supports the latest DDR4 memory for enhanced performance.In conclusion, the AMD Ryzen™ 7 7700X is a powerhouse of a processor that delivers exceptional performance, efficiency, and versatility. Whether you're a gamer, content creator, or power user, this processor is a fantastic investment that will undoubtedly elevate your computing experience. I highly recommend the Ryzen 7 7700X to anyone looking for top-tier performance in a desktop processor.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Quite a beast
reviews.reviewText: This CPU runs very well. Its fast and performs awesome in a heavy game. Just make sure you get a high end cooler for it as it does (intentionally by design) run hot. These we're designed to run at top performance before hitting either the max clock speed or temperature. I definitely recommend this CPU as a mid range AM4 processor.

reviews.reviewText: Ordered it on a Friday night and it came in by Thursdays afternoon so can’t complain about time wise, was completely fine when it arrived, packaging was secure and everything else. And it works perfectly!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2023

reviews.reviewText: Va de maravilla y es muy rápido lo uso la mayoría de las veces con diferentes procesos abiertos y nunca se ralentiza, de la temperatura no podría decir nada por que lo uso con un radiador y anda perfecto, por otra parte el producto llego en perfectas condiciones y en buen tiempo.

reviews.reviewTitle: Runs warm-hot by default, make sure your cooling is optimized
reviews.reviewText: Amazing, Buttery frames in all games at max settings, Fast, Multi monitor, multi window, multi processes and flawless.The CPU runs hotter than normal as mentioned by AMD, Without fan optimization my temps were hitting 77+ sometimes gaming around 85+. However after adjusting the fan curve profile and adjusting positive/negative case pressure, even under extreme loads, usually holds around 85 (-) but for the most part, now sits at around 65 (+-) during all games where as before, would sometimes hover around 88 under heavy loads and now is 40 (+-) idle. Pure Fan cooling here, and my buddies use basic AIO's as to which theirs hold around 61 (+-) under load and 45 (+-) idle. Absolute power house of a CPU, Woulda gone for the 7800x3D but honestly didnt need that much extra power.

Un procesador de nueva generación con una relación calidad/precio de lo mejorcito. Lleva integrada una gráfica por si no quieres poner una dedicada. Te servirá incluso para algunos juegos sin grandes exigencias gráficas.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can safely say 7000 series is more mainstream now
reviews.reviewText: The 7000 series processors are notorious for running at high temperatures, undoubtedly due to higher power consumption and additionally, this is assissted due to the thick IHS.This processor, the 7700x, is fast (really good for mid range CPUs) and I was able to install it without any hiccups.If you have kept up with the news regarding the AM5 motherboards, some of them (specially ASUS, along with some GIGABYTE boards) were literally frying the CPU along with the socket due to the unreasonably high voltage deliveries to the processor. (Additionally, out of the box, AMD has set these processors to run at 95°C, further adding to the problem and they said 'it is MADE to run at 95 degress by design' - still I am a bit uneasy hearing this.)This was the story of nearly a few months to a year ago. HOWEVER, since then, the constant BIOS updates have really stabilized the boards and I can safely say, AM5 platform has stepped into the mainstream territory.Some tips I would suggest, just for the safety, first of all, these new AM5 boards come with 'BiosFlashback' feature so you could update the BIOS to the lastest version without installing anything else. Watch videos for further details.Secondly, I believe the 95°C 'being normal' is uncomfortable for a lot of people. What I did with my ASUS b650 E-F motherboard is that I tweaked the BIOS a bit and undervolted the CPU to 1.20V from 1.30V. Also did some adjustments with the Precision Boost Overdrive (PBO) setting, the Curve optimizer and I set the Thermal throttle limit to 75°C which I feel comfortable with.No doubt, my processor runs at around 95% capacity BUT staying at 75 degrees, I feel much comfortable now. You won't see any noticeable change in performance and your processor stays cool.It's much better to stay safe with these temperatures and expand the lifespan of these processors.Hope this helped :)Edit: It's just over a month since I have been using this processor. Let me mention, the temperature doesn't really go above 60°C and averages around 55 degrees.The only time I hit 75°C was when I stress tested it.My computer is running smooth and I'm really satisfied with the results, the main one being, it is not going supernova.Oh and just to mention, I am using an AIO cooler.
